Monarchies are governments where political power and control rest with a single ruler, often referred to as the "monarch." In tradition or modern sense, monarchs can be king/queen, emperor/empress, or another form of royal designation. Monarchy entails that the office of head of state is usually inherited through familial lineage following hereditary rules and practices.

Here are 5 reasons why some countries still have monarchies:

1. Historical Continuity: Many nations maintain their monarchies primarily for historical purposes â€“ it serves as an enduring tie to their past traditions and legacies. This allows them to preserve their cultural heritage and continue longstanding customs.

2. Symbolic Role: Even in cases where they don't hold real political power (such as constitutional monarchies), a monarchy acts as a symbolic representation of national unity. The non-political role played by the members provides stability and continuity in times of transitions while providing guidance during those changes.

3. Tourism Attraction: Royal families often attract tourists globally who come out to experience the pomp & pageantry associated with traditional ceremonies surrounding sovereign rule; such events may include royal marriages/weddings, funerals/memorials services among several others functions involved around maintaining palaces & Crown properties which contribute economically towards tourism sector.
